#Text=Chapter 1 .
#Text=III
#Text=Mrs. Morgan , wife of a judge of the High Court of Bombay , and I sat amidships on the cool side in the Suez Canal .

#Text=She was outlining ‘ Soiled Linen ’ in chain-stitch on a green canvas bag ; I was admiring the Egyptian sands . ‘ How charming , ’ said I , ‘ is this solitary desert in the endless oasis we are compelled to cross ! ’

#Text=‘ Oasis in the desert , you mean , ’ said Mrs. Morgan ; ‘ I have n’t noticed any , but I happened to look up this morning as I was putting on my stockings , and I saw through my port-hole the most lovely mirage . ’
#Text=I had been at school with Mrs. Morgan more than twenty years agone , but she had come to the special enjoyment of the dignities of life while I still liked doing things .
#Text=Mrs. Morgan was the kind of person to make one realize how distressing a medium is middle age .
#Text=Contemplating her precipitous lap , to which conventional attitudes were certainly more becoming , I crossed my own knees with energy , and once more resolved to be young until I was old .
#Text=‘ How perfectly delightful for you to be taking Cecily out ! ’ said Mrs. Morgan placidly .
#Text=‘ Is n’t it ? ’ I responded , watching the gliding sands .
#Text=‘ But she was born in sixty-nine -- that makes her twenty-one .
#Text=Quite time , I should say . ’
#Text=‘ Oh , we could n’t put it off any longer .
#Text=I mean -- her father has such a horror of early debuts .
#Text=He simply would not hear of her coming before . ’
#Text=‘ Does n’t want her to marry in India , I dare say -- the only one , ’ purred Mrs. Morgan .
#Text=‘ Oh , I do n’t know .
#Text=It is n’t such a bad place .
#Text=I was brought out there to marry , and I married .
#Text=I ’ve found it very satisfactory .
#Text=’
#Text=‘ You always did say exactly what you thought , Helena , ’ said Mrs. Morgan excusingly .

#Text=‘ I have n’t much patience with people who bring their daughters out to give them the chance they never would have in England , and then go about devoutly hoping they wo n’t marry in India , ’ I said .
#Text=‘ I shall be very pleased if Cecily does as well as your girls have done . ’
#Text=‘ Mary in the Indian Civil and Jessie in the Imperial Service Troops , ’ sighed Mrs. Morgan complacently . ‘ And both , my dear , within a year .
#Text=It WAS a blow . ’
#Text=‘ Oh , it must have been ! ’ I said civilly .
#Text=There was no use in bandying words with Emily Morgan .
#Text=‘ There is nothing in the world like the satisfaction and pleasure one takes in one ’s daughters , ’ Mrs. Morgan went on limpidly . ‘ And one can be in such CLOSE sympathy with one ’s girls .
#Text=I have never regretted having no sons . ’
#Text=‘ Dear me , yes .

#Text=To watch oneself growing up again -- call back the lovely April of one ’s prime , etcetera -- to read every thought and anticipate every wish -- there is no more golden privilege in life , dear Emily .
#Text=Such a direct and natural avenue for affection , such a wide field for interest ! ’
#Text=I paused , lost in the volume of my admirable sentiments .
#Text=‘ How beautifully you talk , Helena ! I wish I had the gift . ’
#Text=‘ It does n’t mean very much , ’ I said truthfully .
#Text=‘ Oh , I think it ’s everything !
#Text=And how companionable a girl is ! I quite envy you , this season , having Cecily constantly with you and taking her about everywhere .
#Text=Something quite new for you , is n’t it ? ’
#Text=‘ Absolutely , ’ said I ;
#Text=‘ I am looking forward to it immensely .
#Text=But it is likely she will make her own friends , do n’t you think ? ’ I added anxiously .
#Text=‘ Hardly the first season .
#Text=My girls did n’t .
#Text=I was practically their only intimate for months .
#Text=Do n’t be afraid ; you wo n’t be obliged to go shares in Cecily with anybody for a good long while , ’ added Mrs. Morgan kindly . ‘ I know just how you feel about THAT . ’
#Text=The muddy water of the Ditch chafed up from under us against its banks with a smell that enabled me to hide the emotions Mrs. Morgan evoked behind my handkerchief .
#Text=The pale desert was pictorial with the drifting , deepening purple shadows of clouds , and in the midst a blue glimmer of the Bitter Lakes , with a white sail on them .
#Text=A little frantic Arab boy ran alongside keeping pace with the ship .
#Text=Except for the smell , it was like a dream , we moved so quietly ; on , gently on and on between the ridgy clay banks and the rows of piles .

#Text=Peace was on the ship ; you could hear what the Fourth in his white ducks said to the quartermaster in his blue denims ; you could count the strokes of the electric bell in the wheel-house ; peace was on the ship as she pushed on , an ever-venturing , double-funneled impertinence , through the sands of the ages .
#Text=My eyes wandered along a plank-line in the deck till they were arrested by a petticoat I knew , when they returned of their own accord .
#Text=I seemed to be always seeing that petticoat .
#Text=‘ I think , ’ resumed Mrs. Morgan , whose glance had wandered in the same direction , ‘ that Cecily is a very fine type of our English girls .

#Text=With those dark grey eyes , a LITTLE prominent possibly , and that good colour -- it ’s rather high now perhaps , but she will lose quite enough of it in India -- and those regular features , she would make a splendid Britannia .
#Text=Do you know , I fancy she must have a great deal of character .
#Text=Has she ? ’
#Text=‘ Any amount .
#Text=And all of it good , ’ I responded , with private dejection .
